Ravare-Augustine. Liz Leger (left) is presented. The award is presented annually by the Avoyelles Journal. In 2020 the newspaper broke with tradition and named all "essential workers" fighting the COVID pandemic as the Avoyellean of the Year. Police Juror Charles Jones was the 2019 recipient, being recognized for the many years of public service, first as a career U.S. Army officer, as an educator in the public schools and for his work in promoting civil rights in the parish prior to being elected to public office. {Avoyelles Sleeves Up Facebook photo} Regardless of one’s personal views on the COVID pandemic, an undisputed fact is that anti-COVID vaccines have saved many lives — worldwide, in the U.S., in Louisiana and in Avoyelles Parish. That being the case, it must also be undisputed that many people in this parish have received a potentially life-saving immunization due to the efforts of the 2021 Avoyellean of the Year: Liz Leger. When a few staff members from the local newspaper dropped by the new offices for the Avoyelles Sleeves Up Health Resources organization, she thought it was to discuss some ideas she had for continuing to encourage people to get vaccinated and take booster shots to protect themselves from the current COVID variant and whatever new variant may be lurking in the shadows waiting to launch a “sixth wave” of the two-year pandemic. In tow behind the newspaper reps was another group that included a few former Avoyelleans of the Year and other notable figures. When Liz saw former AoY recipient Theresa Thevenote holding what looked like a plaque, she laughingly said, “I smell a skunk.” While expressing her appreciation and total surprise at receiving the Avoyelles Journal’s annual honor, she quickly said the award “should go to the Avoyelles Sleeves Up team. They do all the hard work.” IMPROVE RURAL ACCESS Avoyelles Sleeves Up was Liz’s idea, born out of her realization that almost all attention at halting COVID-19 with the vaccines was focused on the large cities. Meanwhile, COVID was running rampant and unchecked in rural Louisiana. There was an obvious need to improve rural residents’ access to the potentially life-saving vaccine. She also realized that rural communities were more suspicious of government-sponsored medical programs and more politically opposed to many of the COVID restrictions that had been put in place. With attitude and access being two high hurdles to overcome, Leger and a small cadre of assistants began developing what has become a model for rural vaccination programs throughout the state. One of the group of well-wishers, Van Roy, said Liz was worthy of the honor because “of the courage it took for you to take the stance you did at the time you did.” Roy said she not only had the courage to take that stance, but the persistence and dedication to stick with the project to make it successful. Liz and her husband, Al, live on Johnson Road, outside of Marksville. They have lived in this area for 40 years. She said her 35 year as Department of Education Program for Children with Disabilities administrator for Region 6 and then for the entire state served her well because she still has contacts in other parishes that have helped the local program. She and other Avoyelles Sleeves Up workers are helping other rural parishes develop a similar outreach effort. She will be heavily involved in the upcoming Cenla Rural Vaccination Summit, to be held in Alexandria on March 10. NEIGHBORHOOD EVENTS The local grassroots program has received financial assistance with grants and has recently been allowed to have two nurses that will be conducting community vaccination clinics without the National Guard presence. Liz noted that she received comments from some communities expressing distrust of the military’s involvement in the vaccination program. She believes those reservations will be set aside with the nurse-led programs, which will be held from 10-5 p.m. on those days. Avoyelles Sleeves Up launched its community vaccination drive with the help of the National Guard and nine community teams in the parish — people in those communities that Liz said "give us the \'boots on the ground\' to wage this fight. This brought the vaccine to the neighborhoods, rather than expecting those residents to travel to a few locations to receive the vaccine. Before that effort began, only 16 percent of Avoyelles Parish residents had been vaccinated. As of today, almost 50 percent of parish residents eligible to receive the vaccine are fully vaccinated. Over 50 percent of Avoyelleans have received at least one dose of an anti-COVID vaccine. While there has been improvement, the fight is still tough and far from over, Liz said. One major emphasis at this time is in the area of boosters. WHAT IS ‘FULLY VACCINATED’ The term “fully vaccinated” may have given many a false sense of security. Liz stresses the vaccine is proven to be safe and highly effective at preventing serious COVID infections. The vaccine has reduced the number of people going to the hospital and the number of COVID-related deaths. However, it is not an impenetrable shield against COVID — especially the Omicron variant. Still, she adds, it is better to have even just one dose of a vaccine than to be completely unprotected. There are some who have advocated doing away with the “fully vaccinated” term, arguing that being without a booster means they are not “fully vaccinated.” As of last week, about 6,000 of the almost 19,000 “fully vaccinated” individuals in Avoyelles Parish had received a booster shot — only 31.5 percent. While one member of the award group said that it is hoped that someday in the near future, Liz and the Avoyelles Sleeves Up organization will be able to focus their energy and talents on tackling other community health concerns because COVID will be defeated, Liz made it clear that there is still too much to do to protect the parish from a virus that keeps changing and coming back. With about half of the parish population completely unprotected and less than a third truly “fully vaccinated,” there is still too much opportunity for a new surge to sweep through the parish, sickening thousands, hospitalizing hundreds and killing dozens. DELCAMBRE — People from the town of Delcambre said their goodbyes this past week to the biggest fan of Delcambre High School. That honor belonged to Brittney Jaide Migues, 37, who died after a short illness. Known as “BJ” to the town of Delcambre, Migues spent most of her life in a wheelchair. She was diagnosed with Muscular Dystrophy at the age of one. But that never slowed her down. Her mom, Sandy, remembers Brittney telling her in grade school that she was not handicap. She “just could not walk.” That is how she treated her life. She never let the wheelchair slow her down. With the help of her parents, Sandy and Benny, Brittney was at every Delcambre sporting event. At the football games, her family sat west of the stadium near the scoreboard. At basketball games, she sat to the right when you walked onto the court. She wore her orange and black proudly. For baseball and softball games, she helped keep the scorebook. This past Friday, the Migues family attended a Delcambre football game for the first time without Brittney. They had just buried their daughter that Tuesday. Despite the pain, they attended and were overwhelmed with what had taken place. A group of seniors set up an orange chair with the balloons “B” and “J” tied where Brittney would generally sit for football games. Before the game, a line of DHS senior football player, managers and cheerleaders stood in a straight line and walked up the chair and placed an orange rose on the chair. In honor of their most loyal fan, a white cross with the initials “BJ” was painted in the end zone. “It was awesome,” said Sandy on Sunday night. “We sat and watched as everyone dropped a rose. It was beautiful.” Delcambre head football coach Artie Liuzza was proud of DHS for honoring Brittney. “I thought it was incredible,” said Liuzza. “This is what the Delcambre community is all about. I am proud of the kids and the community.” Delcambre Principal Chantel Helms said the DHS students thought of Brittney as a “big sister.” “I really do not think the student athletes thought of her as a classmate,” said Helms. “I think they thought of her as a big sister. One that was always there to support her little brothers and sisters at every sports event.” Helms said Brittney did not mind stating what the coaches should be calling or what skill the players were lacking or what position they should be playing. “We all took that with love, the same love that she had for the Delcambre Panthers,” said Helms. For the funeral, Delcambre students wore orange shirts and lined the sidewalk and inside the church as Brittney and her family made their way to the front of the church. She was buried in an orange t-shirt with the number 70528 (the town of Delcambre’s zip code) on the chest. Sandy said the Delcambre community, including the school, have been overwhelming with support. Brittney did not let a wheelchair slow her down. She loved going to concerts, the beach, and other sporting events and eating out with friends and family. Before she passed away, the school had planned to name Brittney the grand marshal of the homecoming parade. Despite her death, the school will honor Brittney as the grand marshal, with a float that will be filled with family members. This Tuesday will mark the first week of Brittney’s funeral. During that time, the Migues family realizes how much Brittney did and how much she was a massive part of the family. She helped pay the family bills online and organized trips and events. They just spent their first painful week without the daughter. “It has been empty,” said her mom. “We are lost. She did everything for us.” Looking back, Brittney was not expected to live past 10 years old after being diagnosed with Werdnig Hoffman Disease, a type of Muscular Dystrophy. But, somehow, she beat the odds and lived life to its fullest for 37 years. The Migues dedicated their life to raising their only child. And based on the support the community of Delcambre paid homage to her, it looks like they did a great job.
